issue.title: sdformat-sdf 3.x package does not work well with libsdformat2

content.raw:
The change probably came in [this pull request](#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/188/adding-iterations-to-state/diff). 

A possible solution is: do not use `uint64_t` key and use the existing `int` type. Keep the support for uint64_t in place and modify only the sdf definition. This seems to work for me on both gazebo5 and gazebo6 (tested with recording/playing simulations). Pull request #203. Note that if we rename the sdformat-sdf file (sdformat3-sdf) we probably won't be able to co-install libsdformat2 and libsdformat3.
content.html:
The change probably came in this pull request.

A possible solution is: do not use uint64_t key and use the existing int type. Keep the support for uint64_t in place and modify only the sdf definition. This seems to work for me on both gazebo5 and gazebo6 (tested with recording/playing simulations). Pull request #203. Note that if we rename the sdformat-sdf file (sdformat3-sdf) we probably won't be able to co-install libsdformat2 and libsdformat3.

issue.title: sdformat-sdf 3.x package does not work well with libsdformat2

content.raw: Compiling gazebo5 from source seems to work. Is another solution just to release a new version of gazebo5? We need to do this anyway in order to fix the ogre1.9 problem.
content.html: Compiling gazebo5 from source seems to work. Is another solution just to release a new version of gazebo5? We need to do this anyway in order to fix the ogre1.9 problem.

issue.title: sdformat-sdf 3.x package does not work well with libsdformat2

content.raw:
I haven't tried to compile gazebo5 from source while using the combo: libsdformat2_2.3.2 + sdformat-sdf_3.0.0 but looking into the code, while the change to the Param.hh would include uint64_t into the supported types, I would say that [this piece that is inside Param.cc](#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/188/adding-iterations-to-state/diff#Lsrc/Param.ccT68) is needed no to fall into the `Unknown parameter type`. I could be wrong, but prefer not to risk.

We probably want to keep gazebo5 depending on sdformat2, so I'm afraid that recompile using sdformat-sdf_3.0.0 is not an option. If we count that gazebo5/sdformat2 is inside Ubuntu Vivid (and used in ROS), our margin to make new compatible versions is narrow.
 
For me, it makes sense to keep compatibility during the whole SDF 1.5 series (like having an API), which probably means not to add a breaking change and, if needed, push them into an SDF 1.6. I see the sdformat-sdf package as somewhat sdformat-sdf1.5.
content.html:
I haven't tried to compile gazebo5 from source while using the combo: libsdformat2_2.3.2 + sdformat-sdf_3.0.0 but looking into the code, while the change to the Param.hh would include uint64_t into the supported types, I would say that this piece that is inside Param.cc is needed no to fall into the Unknown parameter type. I could be wrong, but prefer not to risk.

We probably want to keep gazebo5 depending on sdformat2, so I'm afraid that recompile using sdformat-sdf_3.0.0 is not an option. If we count that gazebo5/sdformat2 is inside Ubuntu Vivid (and used in ROS), our margin to make new compatible versions is narrow.

For me, it makes sense to keep compatibility during the whole SDF 1.5 series (like having an API), which probably means not to add a breaking change and, if needed, push them into an SDF 1.6. I see the sdformat-sdf package as somewhat sdformat-sdf1.5.

issue.title: sdformat-sdf 3.x package does not work well with libsdformat2

content.raw:
Ahh, I misunderstood the problem.

Can we specify that libsdformat2 conflicts with sdformat-sdf_3? It seems like we don't need to support libsformat2 operating along side sdformat-sdf_3.0.0.
content.html:
Ahh, I misunderstood the problem.

Can we specify that libsdformat2 conflicts with sdformat-sdf_3? It seems like we don't need to support libsformat2 operating along side sdformat-sdf_3.0.0.

issue.title: sdformat-sdf 3.x package does not work well with libsdformat2

content.raw:
I think @\_jrivero_ mentioned somewhere in this thread the desire to install sdformat versions 2 and 3 side-by-side, which would be one reason to share an sdformat-sdf package. There are several other things standing in the way of side-by-side installs, such as the cmake config files both being named `SDFormatConfig.cmake` without a version number.

It's an interesting concept to make sdformat-sdf behave like sdformat-sdf1.5 and be backward compatible. It doesn't have the same type of API/ABI concept as a C++ library though, so I'm not sure how to check it robustly.
content.html:
I think @_jrivero_ mentioned somewhere in this thread the desire to install sdformat versions 2 and 3 side-by-side, which would be one reason to share an sdformat-sdf package. There are several other things standing in the way of side-by-side installs, such as the cmake config files both being named SDFormatConfig.cmake without a version number.

It's an interesting concept to make sdformat-sdf behave like sdformat-sdf1.5 and be backward compatible. It doesn't have the same type of API/ABI concept as a C++ library though, so I'm not sure how to check it robustly.

issue.title: sdformat-sdf 3.x package does not work well with libsdformat2

content.raw:
We could, and release a new version of sdformat2 for OSRF but the sdformat2 already in Ubuntu can not be updated this way. The most natural way would be to use a different name for sdformat-sdf, something like sdformat-sdf3, but I would like to avoid it if possible.

I see design and releasing benefits of having a co-installable libsdformat versions. Third party binary packages depending on libsdformat2 can still working even if the user is developing on libsdformat3-dev, for example. For example, it should be possible to have gazebo5 in the system and compile gazebo default.

Did you see risk in the patch proposed to keep sdf1.5 implemented in the pull request? If we detect risk, we should proceed with renaming the package, but I want to see this as a last resource this time.
content.html:
We could, and release a new version of sdformat2 for OSRF but the sdformat2 already in Ubuntu can not be updated this way. The most natural way would be to use a different name for sdformat-sdf, something like sdformat-sdf3, but I would like to avoid it if possible.

I see design and releasing benefits of having a co-installable libsdformat versions. Third party binary packages depending on libsdformat2 can still working even if the user is developing on libsdformat3-dev, for example. For example, it should be possible to have gazebo5 in the system and compile gazebo default.

Did you see risk in the patch proposed to keep sdf1.5 implemented in the pull request? If we detect risk, we should proceed with renaming the package, but I want to see this as a last resource this time.
